comment._content: But where are the Police?

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Thought that was Harpo Marx on the left.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: And I can't work out who the chap in the middle of the front row is supposed to be! But I'm going out on an limb and tagging with Pirates of Penzance, if that's ok with all of you. We can revisit if someone comes up with a better solution.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I was going to say Peter Pan, but there is no fairy above...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: We're all thinking light opera and those musicals that we are familiar with today but that shot was taken 100 years ago!  I believe that it was more likely to be a drama and possibly a contemporary one at that.  The AOH would have been very nationalistic and the costumes appear to be set around the time of the revolution in France.  Dion Boucicoult (spelling???) or some similar author was probably as likely as any.  The one apparently dress outfit that is out of sync is that of the butcher/baker/candle-stick-maker seated at the front.   That may lend credence to the statement that it was a fancy dress but he didn't wish to be too fancy!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The guy in the middle front seems to be a shopkeeper, or a butcher, or maybe a surgeon?

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Wow - look at that ladder, excellent work. It's very well put together from malleable iron fittings and pipework !

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Would such pipework and fittings have been mass-produced at this time, Stu?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Indeed they were. There were quite a number of manufacturers in Britain, but over the past 50 years most have disappeared due to foreign competition with cheaper malleable pipe fittings. 

However, I know of one company that has been producing such pipe fittings for well over a hundred years now - George Fischer Ltd. They are more expensive than most others but the quality of their fittings is second to none with regards to service as well as casting and threads - but then again, good quality sells.

PS:
Forgot to mention - these fittings could also be of wrought iron but wrought iron pipe fittings are very much more costly. Malleable pipe fittings will do well outdoors too.
